channel.title: maGaming RSS Feed
channel.description: A cleaned-up version of the original gaming feed

item.title: Surprise! Capcom Is Bringing Pragmata To Switch 2, Demo Out Today
item.content:encoded:
Pre-orders are also live

At The Game Awards preshow, it's been announced Capcom will be bringing Pragmata to the Switch 2 on 24th April 2026.

Pre-orders are now live, and a demo is coming out later for Switch 2 and other console platforms, so you'll be able to try it out before the full release next year. This is a new IP from Capcom, focused on science fiction action-adventure gameplay with a "hacking twist".

"It is the near future, and protagonists Hugh and his android companion Diana, must work together as they make their way through the cold lunar research station."

You can find out a little more about this upcoming release from Capcom in a preview over on sibling site Push Square:

Would you be interested in playing this title on the Switch 2? Let us know in the comments.

Liam is a news writer and reviewer across Hookshot Media. He's been writing about games for more than 15 years and is a lifelong fan of many iconic video game characters.

  • Author Profile
  • Bluesky
  • Reply


https://www.nintendolife.com/news/2025/12/surprise-capcom-is-bringing-pragmata-to-switch-2-demo-out-today
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Pragmata release date confirmed, and it’s coming to Switch 2, and there’s a demo!
item.content:encoded:
After years of delays, Capcom has confirmed the release date for their astronaut and girl action adventure Pragmata. The game will launch on 24th April for PS5, Xbox Series X|S, PC and… Switch 2! Oh, and there’s a demo out today for PC, coming to other platforms soon.

Hugh the astronaut has popped over to the Moon to figure out what’s gone wrong at a big lunar base. After getting split from his team, he’s saved by the android that they eventually settle on should be called Diana – short for the less catchy DI02367. The two form a fast bond, not least because Diana can hack the very angry androids with a quick puzzle minigame to enable you to deal damage. This new trailer shows off some big set piece moments that will push that concept as far as possible.

We went hands on with Pragmata earlier this year, writing in our preview of the curious blend of hacking and shooting gameplay, “Hacking enemies becomes a vital part of combat right away, as it’s used to open up their armour and expose weaknesses for you to blast away at with Hugh’s guns. This is far from a simple button tap, or even a button hold, but rather throws up a minigame for you to complete to launch the hack at the targeted enemy. Thankfully, it’s not the most mentally taxing of tasks (at least initially), as the grid appears and you simply need to fill blocks to paint a path to the exit point. Along the way, you’ll want to also pass through marked nodes that will power up the attack, while avoiding those marked as a hazard. It’s very simple stuff, but what makes it feel different is that you need your thumb on the left analogue stick in order to move Hugh and Diana away from any dangers, so directional inputs are instead mapped to the shape or letter face buttons.”

There’s still a lot of mystery surrounding Pragmata, though now there’s a little bit less that when it was announced half a decade ago. First revealed for PS5 in 2020, the game was meant to release in 2022, was delayed to 2023, and then was delayed again with no further date. We finally have that firm release date, which is very nice, and PC players should check out the Steam demo.



https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2025/12/12/pragmata-release-date-confirmed-and-its-coming-to-switch-2-and-theres-a-demo/
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: The Game Awards 2025: all the news and announcements
item.content:encoded:
The Game Awards are back once again to showcase a metric ton of commercials, provide the gaming public with their monthly dose of Muppets, and validate gamers’ opinions on which title should be named the Game of the Year. I don’t wanna say it’s a foregone conclusion what this year’s GOTY will be — Silksong may surprise us — but it’s pretty obvious that Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is the frontrunner and for good reason. It’s netted 12 nominations, the most out of this year’s contenders, including all five craft awards (Direction, Art, Music and Score, Narrative, and Audio Design).

On the announcements side, Crystal Dynamics and Amazon Games are planning something related to the Tomb Raider series. Keighley also probably had plans to reveal big news about Resident Evil: Requiem, but unfortunately it got spoiled early thanks to some leaked key art on the PlayStation Store. Here’s all the news, announcements, and trailers from The Game Awards 2025.

  • Badger, badger, badger.

    If there’s one thing these video game streets need is a good old-fashioned mascot platformer. Bradley The Badger is a mascot that seems to know he’s in a platforming game. In the trailer that debuted during The Game Awards pre-show, he’s transported from his colorful world to one much less fun...then it gets weird.

  • It’s a dog herd sheep world out there.

    The first announcement of the night was extremely adorable with The Free Shepherd, which is launching on the PS5 and Steam in 2027. If you’re looking for some herding action in the meantime, be sure to check out Herdling.

  • Catfish and Crouton are goin’ on the road.

    Ahead of The Game Awards, Compulsion Games has announced that South of Midnight is going multi-platform. The southern gothic action-adventure game, first released on Xbox earlier this year, is coming to PlayStation and Nintendo Switch 2 in spring 2026. Come for the incredibly cool southern folklore inspired narrative, but stay for your adorable companion Crouton and the yarn-spinnin’ Catfish.

  • It’s almost that time.

    The shine may be wearing off The Game Awards, but the show is still often worth a watch if you like catching the latest game reveals. This year’s edition kicks off at 8PM ET, with a pre-show airing 30 minutes before that.

  • The Game Awards are losing their luster

    It’s Game Awards season, y’all. That special time of the year when we gather together to celebrate video games and the people who make them… by watching expensive commercials briefly punctuated by the odd awards speech or musical performance. For better or worse, The Game Awards is the biggest night on the video game event calendar. But with the way things have been going, lately it’s been more “worse” than it has been “better.”

    Between host and industry hypeman Geoff Keighley’s two video game vanity projects, The Game Awards is older and ostensibly more mature than Summer Game Fest. Conceived in 2014 as a way to celebrate both the people who make and play games, the show has always been part awards ceremony, part commercial product. That idea has been executed with varying degrees of success. (Remember the Schick Hydrobot?) But for the last few years, it’s felt like the awards part was increasingly getting in the way of the commercial part.

    Read Article >

  • It’s Expedition 33 vs. the world.

    The Game Awards’ Game of the Year nominees are out: Clair Obscur: Expedition 33, Death Stranding 2: On the Beach, Donkey Kong Bananza, Hades II, Hollow Knight: Silksong, and Kingdom Come: Deliverance II. Expedition 33 got 12 nominations, the most “in TGA history.“

    The show takes place on December 11th.



https://www.theverge.com/games/841973/the-game-awards-2025-annoucements-news-trailers
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Xbox Developer Direct in January Promises To Be Huge
item.content:encoded:
The team at Xbox, including Matt Booty, has just revealed that the next Xbox Developer Direct, scheduled to take place in January 2026, will be huge, but regardless of that, it can’t fit in everything that is launching across the platform in the next year.

In a recent interview, the team teased a phenomenal year for Xbox through 2026, with the imminent launches of some massive titles, and some sizeable anniversaries being lined up.

Next Xbox Developer Direct is Coming Soon

In a recent interview with Variety, Xbox’s Matt Booty spoke about the upcoming Xbox Developer Direct showcase, poised to take place in just a few weeks:

I can’t share exactly what’s there, but we’ve got a lot of stuff that we’re shipping next year. In fact, usually Dev Direct is about highlighting what’s coming up for the year ahead. This year, we’ve got more stuff coming up than we can fit in one show.

So I will tell you that Playground Games is going to be in the Dev Direct, but we’ll have more stuff next year to ship than we can fit into one Dev Direct show in January, which is a good place to be.

He went on to talk about all the good things happening for Team Green through 2026:

For us, it’s really going to be a great year. It’s going to be the 25th anniversary of Xbox, we’re coming up on franchises of ours that have got these decade-level anniversaries.

It’s the 40th anniversary of Bethesda, Blizzard’s 35, ‘Diablo’ shipped 30 years ago. We’ve announced things like the ‘Halo Remastered’ collection that we’ve got coming, and we’ve got a lot of other things that we’ll talk about soon, that ship next year. So it’s going to be a real banner year for the brand and a banner year for some of our biggest franchises to show up across the industry.

Booty also took the opportunity to address the developing Call of Duty movie, explaining how good a pick Taylor Sheridan is as the project’s writer.

If you think about the way that he tells stories, you think about the other things that he’s been a writer on, I think that the team feels that he’s got a good approach to characters and a good approach to story that’ll match up with their vision of what a ‘Call of Duty’ movie is.

What do you expect from the next Xbox Developer Direct? Let us know on the Insider Gaming Discord server.

For more Insider Gaming coverage, check out the news that South of Midnight is coming to PS5

MOBILE APP

Level Up Your Gaming News

Real-time news, exclusive podcasts, push alerts, and a better reading experience.

Available on Android



https://insider-gaming.com/next-xbox-developer-direct-promises-huge/

item.title: Deadzone: Rogue - Zone 4 Apophis Release Date Exclusive
item.content:encoded:
The Zone 4: Apophis Content Update for Deadzone: Rogue is launching on December 17

Roguelite FPS Deadzone: Rogue just got a release date for its newest free DLC, Zone 4 - Apophis. It will add new missions and story to the game, along with new enemies and encounters, more weapons, as well as adding extra systems, elements, perks, and augments. The Zone 4: Apophis Content Update for Deadzone: Rogue is launching on December 17, and as an added bonus that date also marks the start of a free-to-play access period if you haven't had a chance to jump in yet.

Deadzone: Rogue was officially released in August this year on PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X|S, and PC, and is currently rocking a Very Positive ranking on Steam. You can play solo or with co-op team of up to 3 players, and puts you on board the colony ship ISS-X, which is unfortunately also home to facing murderous robots and mutants. Ain't that always the way?

It's the work of indie studio Prophecy Games, which was original part of the Hi-Rez Studios group but went solo in 2020. It's other game is Tribes 3: Rivals, a team-based first person shooter.

Rachel Weber is the Senior Editorial Director of Games at IGN and an elder millennial. She's been a professional nerd since 2006 when she got her start on Official PlayStation Magazine in the UK, and has since worked for GamesIndustry.Biz, Rolling Stone and GamesRadar. She loves horror, horror movies, horror games, and French Bulldogs. Those extra wrinkles on her face are thanks to going time blind and staying up too late finishing every sidequest in RPGs like Fallout and Witcher 3.

In This Article



https://www.ign.com/articles/deadzone-rogue-zone-4-apophis-release-date-exclusive

item.title: GPTRACK50 announces action RPG Stupid Never Dies for PS5, PC
item.content:encoded:
• PC
  • PS5

Brave a deadly dungeon to bring back the frozen human you loved.

GPTRACK50, the studio led by former Capcom producer Hiroyuki Kobayashi, has announced action RPG Stupid Never Dies for PlayStation 5 and PC (Steam). It will launch in 2026.

Here is an overview of the game, via its Steam page:

Werewolves, Lizardmen, Skeletons—In a world where monsters are part of everyday life, a bottom-rung zombie named Davy braves a deadly dungeon to bring back Julia, the frozen human he loved. Gear up for a delightfully wild, “BLAZING FAST GROWTH” action RPG—Stupid Never Dies!

Set in a monster-ruled otherworldly dungeon, Stupid Never Dies puts you in control of Davy, a timid zombie living at the very bottom of monster society. Defeat enemies, level up, and collect strange items to grow stronger on your quest to bring Julia, a frozen human girl, back to life.

Steal enemy abilities, customize your undead body with bizarre upgrades, and experience fast-paced combat packed with innovation.

Developed by GPTRACK50, a new studio formed by veteran action game developers, Stupid Never Dies delivers a single-player 3D action RPG experience unlike anything you’ve played before.

Watch the announcement trailer below.

Announce Trailer



https://www.gematsu.com/2025/12/gptrack50-announces-action-rpg-stupid-never-dies-for-ps5-pc

item.title: PRAGMATA adds Switch 2 version, launches April 24, 2026
item.content:encoded:
Hacking action adventure game PRAGMATA will launch for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, Switch 2, and PC via Steam on April 24, 2026, Capcom announced. The Switch 2 version is newly announced. A demo is available now for PC, and is coming later for consoles.

Here is an overview of the game, via Capcom:

Set in a dystopian near-future on Earth’s Moon, PRAGMATA will take you on an unforgettable, adventure, powered by the next generation of gaming hardware.

Our development team is hard at work on this brand new game title, making full use of new next-gen tech, such as ray-tracing, to create a breathtaking and immersive sci-fi setting like never before.

Watch a new trailer below.

Trailer

Japanese

item.title: Atmospheric adventure game the free shepherd announced for PS5, PC
item.content:encoded:
Frame Interactive has announced atmospheric adventure game the free shepherd for PlayStation 5 and PC. It will launch in 2027.

Here is an overview of the game, via Frame Interactive:

the free shepherd is a single player atmospheric adventure where you are an energetic and loyal sheepdog. Run fast and free in a beautiful but troubled world. Herd masses of lost sheep to a secret refuge. Discover a mysterious calamity that only you can stop.

Watch the announcement trailer below. View the first screenshots at the gallery.

item.content:encoded:

You can get your hands on a demo for Pragmata right now, after you catch the new trailer.

This year's Game Awards didn't waste any time before dropping some news. Capcom's upcoming sci-fi title, Pragmata, finally has a release date: April 24, 2026. But if you want to get your hands on the game early, the Pragmata demo is available right now.

item.title: Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 Is GameSpot's Game Of The Year 2025
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Here's why Sandfall Interactive's debut title is deserving of our highest accolade

In 2023, Final Fantasy Final Fantasy XVI producer Naoki Yoshida indicated his distaste for the term JRPG, saying that Square Enix doesn't go into its games trying to make a JRPG. "We go into them thinking we're going to create RPGs," he explained.

Before this, Nintendo producer Hitoshi Yamagami, who worked with MonolithSoft on Xenoblade Chronicles X, echoed similar sentiments, saying, "I feel like we just make RPGs, I don't need anyone to add the 'J', personally."

In these two instances, there is both a direct and an implied acknowledgement that although there can be positive connotations attached to the label, "JRPG" can also feel limiting and discriminatory.

Over time, the term JRPG has felt more and more outdated, partly because Japanese developers have expressed opposition to the pigeonholing of their art, and partly because the characteristics that were typically used to demarcate a JRPG have become less and less exclusive to Japanese developers.

Final Fantasy, in particular, underwent a noticeable evolution in style and substance that made it more appealing to western audiences--Shonen-esque narratives have given way to stories aimed at older audiences, and a shift away from turn-based battles has given combat a more action-oriented flow.

As new generations of people have stepped into the roles of creators and designers on games inspired by the Japanese titles they loved playing, the hallmarks of what made a so-called JRPG have broken out of any kind of geographical attachment they may have been saddled with.

There is no clearer example of this than Clair Obscur: Expedition 33, a game that, by its developers' own admission, is inspired by role-playing games developed in Japan, but was created by a small team of developers in France. It is a triumphant testament to the universality and potential of what those games offered then and still do now.

Why Clair Obscur Expedition 33 Is GameSpot's Game of the Year 2025

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

The framework of Expedition 33 can very easily be traced back to specific classics and iconic franchises, such as Final Fantasy 10 and 8; The Legend of Zelda; Kingdom Hearts 2; and the Saga series. However, it also draws from more recent games, such as Nier: Automata, Sekiro, and Dark Souls. But what makes Expedition 33 special is that all of its inspirations are brought together in a way that is unique to itself, its creators, and the time in which it was made and released.

Expedition 33 feels like an all-time classic role-playing game that has just been rediscovered. It shows where the genre could have gone had it not pivoted after Mistwalker's Lost Odyssey. In that way, it is a love letter to an era of role-playing games that has been lost to time.

And at the same time, Expedition 33 is able to proudly stand alongside contemporaries thanks to its utterly bewitching storytelling, which deals with heavy subject matter such as grief, the value of life, and the perils of not being able to let go. It explores all of this with elegant writing and spellbinding performances that, together, make for profound emotional moments of empathy and understanding. It's a game about death that, somehow, is also able to inspire hope and find humor amid its darkness.

This is all driven by a thrilling sense of adventure that pushes players to explore surreal environments as they go toe-to-toe with everything from shockingly powerful mimes to enigmatic divine entities with the ability to remove thousands of lives from existence with the stroke of a brush. Its turn-based format, reactive combat, and character development systems may be a combination of familiar ideas, but it's all deftly married together in a way that makes it satisfying to engage with. At every step, carefully crafting roles and strategies is compelling, and the pure joy of perfectly timing a parry to survive impossible odds never dulls.

More impressively is how developer Sandfall Interactive does all this while also presenting the game with an unmatched style. Expedition 33's otherworldly visuals give its setting a dreamlike quality, and the hauntingly beautiful soundtrack emphasizes the melancholic nature of the journey players go on. The studio triumphantly draws from French artistry and culture to provide a window into not just an unforgettable fantasy world, but the real world, too, and how it has shaped the people behind Expedition 33's creation.

Like Yoshida and Yamagami, Sandfall set out to make an RPG that anyone can find value in experiencing. And what Expedition 33 became, and is about, proves that artistic expression doesn't belong to a single group of people or a place, and that there is no such thing as a JRPG--there are just ideas that have the power to move and inspire people, and that can be realized in ways that feel deeply personal to and representative of those that bring them to life.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com



https://www.gamespot.com/articles/clair-obscur-expedition-33-is-gamespots-game-of-the-year-2025/1100-6536771/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Pragmata Comes To Switch 2 And Other Platforms Next April – And A Demo Drops Today
item.content:encoded:
This year's Game Awards wasted no time getting to the big announcements, dropping huge news about one of Capcom's biggest upcoming games during the half hour before Geoff Keighley even took the stage. Pragmata, the sci-fi action adventure game we've been waiting on for years now, is officially launching on April 24, 2026, and there's a demo available to try today on Steam. You can check out the new trailer for yourself below.

The new glimpse primarily focuses on the bond between the protagonist Hugh and the child-like android Diana he's tasked with protecting. After roughly a minute of new footage, the two high five to announce the release date. Additionally, we learn that the game is coming to Switch 2 as well, seemingly on the same day as PS5, Xbox Series X/S, and PC. Finally, there's a demo launching today on Steam, but it will come to other platforms, including Switch 2, "later."

For more on Pragmata, you can check out our hands-on preview of the game from earlier this year. For more on this year's Game Awards, check out our round-up of all of this year's winners.



https://gameinformer.com/the-game-awards-2025/2025/12/11/pragmata-comes-to-switch-2-and-other-platforms-next-april-and-a
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Mario + Rabbids creator's next game spoofs Bloodborne and more, in a mascot platformer parody of the games industry starring a badger
item.content:encoded:
The creator of Mario + Rabbids has revealed his next game, and it's a send up of the games industry as a mascot platformer: Bradley the Badger.

Davide Soliani - affectionately known as Ubisoft Crying Man - joined with writer Christian Cantamessa (Red Dead Redemption, Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor) to found new studio Day 4 Night. Bradley the Badger is its first game.

The adventure will blend live-action and animation as the titular creature explores a variety of unfinished worlds and would-be reboots of his series, each a different genre, as a parody of the games industry - it's been compared to Wreck-it Ralph and Who Framed Roger Rabbit.

Key to gameplay is The Kit, which allows Bradley to modify unfinished assets and solve puzzles, while smacking enemies with a frying pan.

And it looks like there will be plenty of tongue-in-cheek game references too. Badgerborne I'm very interested in.

"We wanted to make something that would reignite us, something capable of taking us back in time to when, with younger eyes, the whole world of videogames seemed to shine," said Soliani. "And we wanted our mechanics to be the perfect bridge between the past and the future."

"Bradley is part love letter to videogames and part satire of them," added Cantamessa. "Games are an art form and this is a story inspired by our adventures making them. From the inner turmoil of self-doubt to the joy of building worlds, we set out to transform those experiences into a game that anyone can get lost in."

Soliani departed from Ubisoft last year after 25 years at Ubisoft, 11 of which were spent on the Mario + Rabbids tactics games for Nintendo Switch. "I have decided to leave Ubisoft to embark on a new adventure," he said at the time. "I can't say more now. Thanks a lot for everything, truly."

Then earlier this year, the developer pair revealed Day 4 Night, stating they were working on a "passion project".

Soliani noted there's "a growing interest from the player towards games that are a bit, let's say, out of the chorus. They are a bit different. They are willing to tell different stories…that's what we are observing as developers and as players."

Bradley the Badger certainly seems to fit the bill.

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/mario-rabbids-creators-next-game-spoofs-bloodborne-and-more-in-a-mascot-platformer-parody-of-the-games-industry-starring-a-badger
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Xbox Is Bringing Another Game To Switch 2 In Spring 2026
item.content:encoded:
Compulsion Games' South of Midnight

Xbox is now bringing its games to other platforms, and following a bunch of announcements in recent years, another first-party title has been locked in.

South of Midnight by Compulsion Games will coming to the Switch 2 (and PS5) in Spring 2026. This title originally made its debut on the Xbox Series X|S earlier this year in April.

If you're not familar with this title it's a third-person action-adventure described as being set in a "magic realist version of American South". You can find out more about it in a review on Pure Xbox:

Would you be interested in this game? Let us know in the comments.

Liam is a news writer and reviewer across Hookshot Media. He's been writing about games for more than 15 years and is a lifelong fan of many iconic video game characters.

item.title: The Free Shepherd is a game where you get to be a very good dog
item.content:encoded:
The Free Shepherd has been revealed by Frame Interactive, an atmospheric adventure where a border collie has lost all their sheep! The game is set to release for PC and PS5 in 2027.

It’s a very Little Bo-Peep kind of story, where all of the sheep this sheepdog has been looking after have disappeared, so you’ll set out to find them across a sweeping landscape. It is rather lovely looking, especially with a very expressively animated star at its heart.

I'm probably wearing toe shoes, and there's nothing you can do to stop me!

Related stories from TSA



https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2025/12/12/the-free-shepherd-is-a-game-where-you-get-to-be-a-very-good-dog/
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: South of Midnight Arrives on PS5 and Nintendo Switch 2 in Spring 2026
item.content:encoded:
South of Midnight will make its inevitable arrival on PS5 and Nintendo Switch 2 in Spring 2026, developer Compulsion Games announced tonight ahead of The Game Awards 2025. It's the latest previously Xbox Series X/S console exclusive title to arrive on other platforms, and in this case, it seems like Compulsion Games could be aiming to get it out on other platforms right on the anniversary.

The news was announced with a post on the studio's Bluesky account, with a short statement and graphic confirming the news, though interestingly, only the graphic included a mention of the PS5 version.

South of Midnight arrived earlier this year on April 8, 2025, and if Compulsion is aiming for sometime in Spring next year, it could just be aiming for April 8, 2026, or that same week, since April 8, 2026, is a Wednesday, and games are more commonly released either at the beginning or the end of a week.

I reviewed South of Midnight for Wccftech when it arrived earlier this year, and gave it a 7/10, writing, "Overall, South of Midnight has excellent storytelling, excellent artistic and visual design, a wonderful cast of characters and voice actors, and an original soundtrack that punctuates each big narrative beat in a way that will stay with you long after you put the controller down. Unfortunately, the same creativity that went into the rest of the game is missing in its combat and platforming, and Compulsion Games does itself no favors by launching you into the same boring combat scenarios again and again in each level."

Follow Wccftech on Google to get more of our news coverage in your feeds.



https://wccftech.com/south-of-midnight-nintendo-switch-2-ps5-release-date/
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Decrepit is a solo-developed soulslike about escaping a castle by dying in it
item.content:encoded:
Earlier tonight, The Game Awards 2025 briefly ceased funnelling trophies into Sandfall Interactive’s pockets on a heavily sponsored conveyor belt to reveal Decrepit: a horror-flavoured, dungeon-dwelling soulslike that’s the debut project of solo dev outfit Jämmerdal Games. It’s being published by Three Friends, they of Romestead and ex-Mojang/Ghost Ship Games note, and aims to be out in 2026.

Why give two hoots about yet another difficult, dark fantasy ghoulbasher? Firstly, there’s a bit in the trailer where an undead, still shackled to the medieval torture wheel he died on, attacks by rolling himself across the floor like a bigger, blunter homage to Dark Souls' Bonewheel Skeletons, and it might be the funniest thing I’ve seen all night. Second, the setup does sound intriguing: your end goal is escaping a vast castle, and dying will dump you right back at the start – but in a different corner of the fortress each time. A successful breakout, Three Friends say, will rely on you learning the layout and unlocking shortcuts over successive runs; "spatial mastery over power creep", to use their words.

"That’s a roguelike, not a soulslike," an imagined antagonist would argue in my head. It definitely sounds like there’s a bit of that, with weapons and armour needing to be gathered mid-run, though they’ll be pinched off corpses instead of presented as boon options every time you clear a room of twitching monsters. The castle itself remains a constant, in contrast to the semi-randomised zones that come to mind when one thinks of roguelikes; memorizing enemy patrols in certain areas is apparently emphasised, though some recurring baddies might pop up in multiple spots to catch you out.

The influences namedropped by Jämmerdal Games – a.k.a. Starbreeze and Avalanche Studios alumnus Olof Hagelin – include classic first-person magic shooter Hexen: Beyond Heretic and dungeon crawling RPG Eye of the Beholder. “In Decrepit I've tried to recapture that feeling of dread and excitement I felt when I played the old classics for the first time," he says.

I’m too youthful and vibrant, as you can tell from looking at me, to have played these in their prime. But I am keen on further exploring first-person soulslikes, after a friendly first meeting with Napoleonic swordswinger Valor Mortis, and it’s rarely a bad thing when a game manages to make a location feel more than meshes and textures. I want Decrepit’s castle to be a villain, almost as much I want to see more cartwheeling zombies.



https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/decrepit-is-a-solo-developed-soulslike-about-escaping-a-castle-by-dying-in-it
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: South of Midnight Officially Announced For PS5, Switch 2
item.content:encoded:
South of Midnight developers have just confirmed that the release window for Switch 2 and PS5 is set for Spring 2026.

Compulsion Games’ new action-adventure, South of Midnight, was released for Xbox Series X/S and PC back in April 2025. It seems to have been a timed console exclusivity deal, as the game is finally coming to new platforms, including PlayStation 5 and Nintendo’s latest console, the Switch 2.

South of Midnight Arriving for PS5 and Switch 2 in Spring 2026

Just minutes before the highly anticipated The Game Awards 2025 event, Compulsion Games put out a new post on X (formerly Twitter) confirming South of Midnight’s release on PS5 and Switch 2. The developers didn’t provide a release date, but we do know it is planned for Spring 2026.

In South of Midnight, players embody the role of Hazel, who is a Weaver, a magical mender of broken bonds and spirits. The game features the mythos and creatures of Southern Folklore in a macabre and fantastical world. The protagonist will battle dangerous creatures as she unearths secrets about her family.

Hazel is also tasked with rescuing her mother, saving her hometown, and using her ancient power to restore creatures and uncover the traumas that consume them. The game also features diverse regions of the South, as seen through the decayed county of Prospero and its residents.

In other news, here’s how you have to manually save in South of Midnight. Additionally, the game is available on Xbox Game Pass. What are your thoughts on South of Midnight releasing for Switch 2 and PS5? Leave your thoughts down in the comments, and join the official Insider Gaming Discord server.

For more information from Insider Gaming, read about Tomb Raider Catalyst leaking ahead of The Game Awards. Don’t forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: Another Great Xbox Exclusive Headed To PS5 And Switch 2
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Another great Xbox exclusive, South of Midnight, is heading to rival platforms. Developer Compulsion Games has announced that the action-adventure game is coming to PS5 and Switch 2 in Spring 2026.

South of Midnight launched in April for PC and Xbox Series X|S, meaning it'll be coming to different systems after about a period of a year, depending on when exactly it hits PS5 and Switch 2.

South of Midnight is set in the American Deep South. The game follows the character Hazel, who, along with her mother, are preparing for a huge hurricane.

It's just the latest Xbox exclusive to come to rival platforms. Just this week, Microsoft put Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024 on PS5, while games like Doom: The Dark Ages and The Outer Worlds 2 came to PS5 this year. Next year, Microsoft will launch Halo: Campaign Evolved on PS5.

Microsoft is bringing Xbox games to rival systems to help titles reach a wider audience, and to help Microsoft make more money considering how much larger the PS5 install base is, in particular.

GameSpot's South of Midnight review scored the game a 8/10. "It doesn't exactly wow with its combat and platforming, but these parts of the game are mechanically sound, and South of Midnight's memorable characters, incredible visuals, and catchy soundtrack are so strong that it doesn't really matter that the gameplay is just decent," reviewer Jordan Ramée said.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com



https://www.gamespot.com/articles/another-great-xbox-exclusive-headed-to-ps5-and-switch-2/1100-6536898/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

item.title: Every Winner At The Game Awards 2025 So Far - Updated Live
item.content:encoded:
2025 has been a big year for video games, and the Game Awards aims to concentrate all the successes and enthusiasm into one night of celebration. With musical performances, celebrity guests (Geoff Keighley booked two Muppets this year), and dozens of new game trailers and reveals, it's undeniably one of the biggest industry events of the year.

Whether you tuned in late, missed one of the winners, or chose not to watch at all, this round-up will recap every award. The coveted game of the year trophy will be doled out at the end of the night, but until then, you can continue to check this article, which will be updated live, to see each winner as it's announced.

Here is the full list of nominees (with announced winners in bold):

item.title: Watch: The Game Awards 2025 - Live!
item.content:encoded:
Trophy hunting

Our next dose of Geoff is right around the corner, as we are mere minutes away from The Game Awards 2025.

This year's event kicks off at 5pm PST / 8pm EST / 1am GMT (Fri) / 2am CET (Fri) / 10am JST (Fri), though, as ever, a pre-show 'Opening Act' will begin half an hour before that — and you can expect to see some awards given out there too.

Here's the precise time that you'll be able to tune into the Opening Act in your region:

  • North America: 4:30pm (Thu) PST / 5:30pm (Thu) MST / 6:30pm (Thu) CST / 7:30pm (Thu) EST
  • UK/Ire: 12:30am GMT
  • Europe: 1:30am CET / 2:30am EET
  • Asia/Oceania: 9:30am JST / 8:30am AWST / 11:30am AEDT

Normally, TGAs aren't packed with Switch news, but there are a lot of big hitters we enjoyed on Nintendo consoles this year up for some headline awards. We've got Donkey Kong Bananza, Hollow Knight Silksong, and Hades II all up for GOTY, and Mario Kart World is in the running for a few trophies too.

There's every chance that we'll hear some third-party Switch 2 news from this one, too, with the fresh hybrid still very much being the new kid on the block. Don't go expecting anything from Nintendo itself, but an announcement of a port or two might be on the cards.

Whatever the event throws our way, we'll be here to watch along with you. You can watch the full event — from the Opening Act right up to the final award — and have a natter while you do it, below.



https://www.nintendolife.com/news/2025/12/watch-the-game-awards-2025-live

item.title: South of Midnight coming to PS5, Switch 2 in spring 2026
item.content:encoded:
• PS5
  • Switch 2

Currently available for Xbox Series and PC.

Publisher Xbox Game Studios and developer Compulsion Games will release third-person action–adventure game South of Midnight for PlayStation 5 and Switch 2 in spring 2026, the companies announced (2).

South of Midnight first launched for Xbox Series and PC via Steam and Microsoft Store on April 8, 2025.

Here is an overview of the game, via Xbox Game Studios:

About

From the creators of Contrast and We Happy Few, South of Midnight is a spellbinding third-person action adventure game set in the American Deep South.

As Hazel, you will explore the mythos and encounter creatures of Southern folklore in a macabre and fantastical world. When disaster strikes her hometown, Hazel is called to become a Weaver: a magical mender of broken bonds and spirits. Imbued with these new abilities, Hazel will confront and subdue dangerous creatures, untangle the webs of her own family’s shared past and -if she’s lucky – find her way to a place that feels like home.

Key Features

  • A Dark Modern Folktale – When a hurricane rips through Prospero, Hazel is pulled into a Southern Gothic world where reality and fantasy are interwoven, and ancient creatures from folklore emerge. In this coming-of-age adventure, Hazel journeys forth to rescue her mother and delves into a haunting web of folklore and family secrets, untangling her own identity.
  • Confront Mythical Creatures – Wield an ancient power to restore creatures and uncover the traumas that consume them. Cast weaving magic to fight destructive Haints, explore the diverse regions of the South, and reweave the tears in the Grand Tapestry.
  • Haunting Beauty of the Gothic South – Discover the lush, decayed county of Prospero and its locals. Experience a crafted visual style, touching storytelling, and immersive music inspired by the complex and rich history of the South.


https://www.gematsu.com/2025/12/south-of-midnight-coming-to-ps5-switch-2-in-spring-2026
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Instead of fixing WoW’s new floating house exploit, Blizzard makes it official
item.content:encoded:
In a forum post formally announcing the official UI change, Community Manager Randy “Kaivax” Jordan noted that the team “quickly” got to work on enabling the floating house UI after seeing the community “almost immediately” embrace the glitch. But Kaivax also notes that the undersides of houses were never intended to be visible, and thus “aren’t modeled are textured.” Players who make floating houses “may decide to hide that part behind other things,” Kaivax suggests.

Players with houses that float too high may also have problems positioning the camera so they can click the door to enter the house. For this problem, Kaivax suggests that “you might want to consider building a ramp or a jumping puzzle or a mount landing spot, etc.”

WoW‘s floating houses join a long legacy of beloved game features that weren’t originally intended parts of a game’s design, from Street Fighter II‘s combo system to Doom‘s “rocket jump.” Now if we could only convince Blizzard to make Diablo III gold duplication into an official feature.



https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2025/12/instead-of-fixing-wows-new-floating-house-exploit-blizzard-makes-it-official/
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Sonic The Hedgehog Fans Gotta Go Fast If They Want This Lego Set Deal
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Sonic the Hedgehog fans can save big on one of the Lego playsets that is scheduled to retire before the end of the year. The 393-piece Tails' Adventure Boat is discounted to only $37 (was $55) at Amazon. This is a limited-time Lightning Deal, so it's not expected to remain in stock for long. It's the best Lego Sonic deal we've seen this holiday season, but it's not the only one available right now. We've included a list of every Lego Sonic deal at the end of this story, including a few other soon-to-be discontinued playsets such as Knuckles and the Master Emerald Shrine for $26.24 (was $35).

Lego Sonic: Tails' Adventure Boat (393 pieces)

$37 (was $55) | Limited-time deal

This 393-piece Lego Sonic the Hedgehog playset comes with Tails and Sonic figures, a buildable speedboat, and several smaller builds, including a small island. The boat measures 9 x 4.5 x 4 inches and has multiple interactive elements. Like numerous Lego Sonic sets, it comes with a speed sphere that can be launched from the boat by pushing the lever on the side.

The set also includes a Tocky figure that has been taken by the buildable Jawz. Your objective is to save the little guy by hopping in the speed sphere and taking out Jawz.

Once it's time to relax, you can connect a parasail accessory and water skis to the Sonic figure or visit the island for a picnic, karaoke, and dancing. The island features an archway with a few golden rings that can be snagged by launching the speed sphere through the opening.

Lego Sonic the Hedgehog Deals

Tails' Adventure Boat is one of six Sonic the Hedgehog Lego sets retiring soon. As mentioned, you can also get nice deals on the 325-piece Knuckles and the Master Emerald Shrine and Knuckles' Guardian Mech. The other three retiring-soon sets aren't discounted, but if you like Shadow the Hedgehog, it'd be wise to pick up Shadow's Escape for only $20 before it sells out on Amazon. Other deals include the 747-piece Team Sonic Command Truck for $56 (was $70) and Knuckles vs. Dr. Eggman Egg Crusher Mech for $36 (was $45).

  • Tails' Adventure Boat (393 pieces) -- $37 ($55) | Retiring soon
  • Knuckles and the Master Emerald Shrine (325 pieces) -- $26.24 ($35) | Retiring soon
  • Knuckles' Guardian Mech (276 pieces) -- $30 ($35) | Retiring soon
  • Team Sonic Command Truck (747 pieces) -- $56 ($70)
  • Sonic's Campfire Clash (177 pieces) -- $16 ($20)
  • Knuckles vs. Dr. Eggman Egg Crusher Mech (350 pieces) -- $36 ($45)
  • Cyclone vs. Metal Sonic (290 pieces) -- $28.49 ($30)
  • Shadow's Escape (196 pieces) -- $20 | Retiring soon
  • Super Sonic vs. Egg Drillster (590 pieces) -- $80 | Retiring soon
  • Shadow the Hedgehog Model (720 pieces) -- $70 | Retiring soon

item.title: Apple loses contempt appeal in Epic case
item.content:encoded:
Apple has lost its appeal of a massive district court ruling in its ongoing antitrust dispute with Epic Games.

That April ruling from Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers said that Apple “willingly” failed to comply with a 2021 order allowing mobile app developers to link to payment options outside of Apple’s, and she barred Apple from charging a commission on in-app purchases using external payment links, among other restrictions. In today’s opinion, the three-judge Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals panel largely affirmed Gonzalez Rogers’ contempt findings and the limits on Apple. But it asked the judge to consider options that would let Apple charge reasonable fees for external link purchases.

Gonzalez Rogers’ ruling took issue with a series of moves Apple made to discourage developers from using external payment methods, including adding a 27 percent fee for external payments, requiring developers to restrict links to plain text instead of allowing them to make buttons, and showing users a fullscreen warning when they tapped an external link. The appeals court agreed that “Apple claimed to comply with the injunction, but it instead prohibited developers from using buttons, links, and other calls to action without paying a prohibitive commission to Apple, and it restricted the design of the developers’ links to make it difficult for customers to use them.”

But the appeals court ruling said Gonzalez Rogers had gone too far in one area: prohibiting Apple from collecting any fee on in-app purchases from developers. “Rather than coercing Apple to comply with the spirit of the Injunction with a reasonable, non-prohibitive commission, the district court used blunt force to ban all commissions, abusing its discretion,” according to the opinion.

The panel has recommendations about an “appropriate commission or fee limitation,” including that Apple charge based on the necessary costs for “its coordination of external links for linked-out purchases.”

The opinion also says that while Apple can’t force developers to make their own options less visible or appealing than Apple’s default, it can restrict developers from placing buttons, links, or “other calls to action” in “more prominent fonts, larger sizes, larger quantities, and more prominent places than Apple uses for its own buttons, links, or other calls to action.”

Apple and Epic didn’t immediately reply to a request for comment. Epic CEO Tim Sweeney retweeted posts from Bloomberg and Schaeffer’s Investment Research about the ruling.

Follow topics and authors from this story to see more like this in your personalized homepage feed and to receive email updates.

  • Jay Peters


https://www.theverge.com/news/842991/apple-epic-appeal-loses-contempt
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Team Falcons and The MongolZ Eliminated from Budapest Major Playoffs
item.content:encoded:
Team Falcons and The MongolZ are the first teams to fall from the StarLadder Budapest Major playoffs after both being swept by more capable opponents. Their fixtures ended with a 0-2 scoreline, with Spirit knocking out Falcons and a dominant Vitality squad dispatching The MongolZ.

The fan-favorite sides had sparked hopes of an underdog run through the Budapest playoffs, but it simply wasn’t to be. These two spirited campaigns come to an end, and we move on to day two of the playoffs.

If you want to place a wager on what’s left of the playoffs, Insider Gaming, together with the international betting brand GG.BET, brings you to the heart of unforgettable moments of the StarLadder Major Budapest 2025. Visit gg.bet to dive deeper, place your bets, and feel the adrenaline of esports!

First Eliminations Confirmed

The grand final round of the StarLadder Budapest Major is fast approaching, and one team is lining up to walk away with a massive $500,000 prize. Before that arrives, another five fixtures, including the BO5 grand final, has to take place.

Team Falcons fell short after facing the daunting challenge of Team Spirit, who entered the playoffs in formidable form. Spirit was dominant out of the gate, sweeping the series 2-0 without too much fuss.

It was a similar story for The MongolZ, and despite dishing out earlier upsets against some capable sides, Vitality was just too quickly able to outmaneuver the Mongolian side. It was unsustainable, and another 2-0 sweep brought another chapter of the Major to a close.

The remaining matches are set to be blockbuster fixtures:

  • Team Spirit vs. Team Vitality
  • MOUZ vs. FaZe Clan
  • Natus Vincere vs. FURIA

It’s anyone’s game right now.

Let us know on the Insider Gaming Discord server who you think will win this tournament.

For more Insider Gaming coverage, check out the news that Battlefield REDEC’s tournament was postponed

item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Tomb Raider Catalyst is the winner of this year’s “Someone pressed the TGA button too soon” award
item.content:encoded:
As is tradition, someone somewhere has published information a little too early about a game that is almost certainly going to be revealed later on tonight at The Game Awards. This year Lara Croft can take home not one, but two shiny “Someone pressed the TGA button to soon” awards as two Tomb Raider games have leaked.

The first is Tomb Raider Catalyst, which leaked artwork, synopsis, and the entire trailer, although Amazon has been very quick to take the latter down. It is set for release in 2027 for the PS5, Xbox Series X|S and PC and finds Lara on a new expedition across Northern India.

“Set in the wake of a mythical cataclysm that has unleashed ancient secrets and awakened mysterious guardian forces, Tomb Raider: Catalyst folows Lara Croft on a new adventure across Northern India.”

The second game, Tomb Raider: Legacy of Atlantis, is a “reimagining” of the very first Lara Croft adventure.

“Experience a stunning reimagining of Lara Croft’s 1996 genre-defining game with jaw-dropping visuals, modern gameplay, and new surprises that honor the spirit of the original.”

If you really want to watch the trailer for that then you can find it in super low res with no sound over on 4chan, I suggest you don’t. I had a look on your behalf and it looks very much like the first Tomb Raider but all modern, so exactly what you would expect.

Tomb Raider: Legacy of Atlantis is also coming to PS5, Xbox Series X|S and PC and both games are being made by Crystal Dynamics and published by Amazon.  They are also making a Tomb Raider TV series with  Sophie Turner set to take on the leading role.

Turner, whose breakout role came as Sansa Stark in the Game of Thrones series, before she played Jean Grey in X-Men: Apocalypse and Dark Phoenix, will be the third actor to play Lara Croft. She follows in the footsteps of Angelina Jolie, who starred in two films in the early 2000s, and Alicia Vikander, who had one shot at the role in 2018.

Source: Reddit/videocardz



https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2025/12/11/tomb-raider-catalyst-legacy-of-atlantis/
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: A Super Meat Boy 3D demo is now live
item.content:encoded:
Have you been keen to step into the 3D meat space of Super Meat Boy 3D? Well there’s no need to wait for PC gamers, as a Super Meat Boy 3D demo is now live on Steam.

Coming as a slight precursor to The Game Awards tonight, this is a newly updated version of the demo that was playable at Gamescom earlier this year.

The Super Meat Boy 3D demo features 10 levels from the full game, giving a look at two worlds – the squirrel-infested Forest and the trash-filled Wastes. Of course, this will be just a taster, an apertif for what’s in store, which is laid out by the following blurb:

Super Meat Boy 3D is a brutal platformer that sees you guide a cube of meat on a mission to rescue his bandage-made girlfriend from an evil fetus in a tuxedo jar—IN 3D! You’ll wall-jump past buzz saws, crumbling caves, and flaming forests, dying a million times along the way—IN (you guessed it) 3D. With old-school difficulty, twitchy reflexes, epic bosses, and loads of secrets, it’s Meat Boy like never before—IN (say it with me!) 3D!

Yup, there’s boss fights in this one.

If you don’t have a PC, or want to save the experience for later, hopefully you won’t have to wait too long. Super Meat Boy 3D coming in early 2026 to Xbox Series X|S, PS5 and PC, and coming day one to Game Pass.



https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2025/12/11/a-super-meat-boy-3d-demo-is-now-live/
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Modiphius Announces Fallout: Power Play, a Post-Apocalyptic Strategic Card Game
item.content:encoded:
Pre-orders are now live for Fallout: Power Play. This new card game from Modiphius Entertainment brings a strategic experience to the post-apocalyptic world of Bethesda's iconic action RPG series.

The Fallout: Power Play Pre-Order Announcement

According to an official press release, Fallout: Power Play is a light strategic card game designed for 2-4 players. The game was designed by Resurrectionist Games, the same studio that made the Doom Arena Board Game.

In the game, you take control of one of four factions. Those factions are the Brotherhood of Steel, Enclave, Raiders, and the Super Mutants. From there, you compete to take control of various locations of the Wasteland. This is done by placing agents to gain influence and undertake quests to gain bonuses. In addition, players can use Power Play cards, which can shift the game's dynamic and disrupt enemy strategies.

But the Wasteland isn't so easily tamed. Every turn, a Wasteland card is drawn at random, bringing an unpredictable change to the game. These changes include sudden atomisation to a Deathclaw rampaging through your home base. As for how you can deal with such chaos, you can always play politics with the other faction, make alliances, and keep some backup plans just in case.

“We’ve been making immersive Fallout tabletop games for years - we started with the Fallout wargame experience, and then came the tabletop RPG. But for those wanting a quick, fun taster of Fallout, we’re excited to be bringing them Fallout: Power Play - perfect for playing with friends on their coffee table.” - Chris Birch, Co-Founder of Modiphius

Fallout: Power Play is but one of many tabletop adaptations of the RPG series. Other works include an official Fallout TTRPG, and the miniature skirmish games Fallout: Factions and Fallout: Wasteland Warfare.

Fallout: Power Play is available now on Modiphius' web store at an MSRP of $30, not including shipping. The game is expected to ship in January 2026.

Ever since he was small, Tyler Chancey has had a deep, abiding love for video games and a tendency to think and overanalyze everything he enjoyed. This… More about Tyler

item.title: Elden Ring Nightreign: The Forsaken Hollows Review - Hard Reign
item.content:encoded:
Elden Ring Nightreign represents a real experiment for developer FromSoftware, leaving behind the traditional Soulslike trappings in favor of a more self-contained, run-based gameplay loop.

Despite its departure from what fans of this genre are used to, Nightreign has done pretty well for itself in the sales department. It should come as no surprise, then, that a DLC expansion, The Forsaken Hollows, has darkened its imposing, slow-to-open doors.

The Forsaken Hollows adds two whole new Nightlords with which to do battle, as well as a host of returning bosses from previous Souls titles (and Elden Ring itself, of course), new enemies, and two new characters to get to grips with as well. It's a solid DLC that packs some meaty challenge, but it's not without its flaws.

To put it simply, despite the experimental nature of Elden Ring Nightreign itself, you shouldn't expect anything too crazy and different from The Forsaken Hollows.

This isn't a Prey: Mooncrash situation, in which the DLC completely transforms the nature of the base game; rather, it's an additional chunk of Nightreign for those who loved their time in Limveld.

Depending on what you wanted from Elden Ring Nightreign, that may either come as a relief or an unpleasant surprise. For me, it was the former; I rather liked Nightreign, so I was glad for an excuse to be put back under its weird, wonderful spell.

This DLC's signature feature is its new Shifting Earth condition, which essentially transforms Limveld into a crystal-strewn underground paradise filled with treacherous chasms and precarious bridges.

It feels like an entirely new map, and when you first head into it, you can expect more than your fair share of confusion and untimely death as you learn its layout and its most optimal routes.

That's nothing new for Nightreign; although this new map can be a touch more punishing than Limveld proper, it's still just a matter of spending time with The Forsaken Hollows until you're familiar with the area's contours and pitfalls.

Just like Nightreign itself, I'd very strongly recommend taking two friends with you into this DLC rather than relying on the kindness of strangers.

Nightreign feels like it's built for groups who can communicate beyond the rather limited ping system; there's no built-in voice chat, and The Forsaken Hollows' intricate map and brutal boss fights (more on which in a moment) demand co-ordination.

Boy Howdy, The Forsaken Hollows Sure Is Hard

The base Elden Ring Nightreign experience was no slouch in the difficulty department, and The Forsaken Hollows ratchets things up to a degree that might test your limits if you found Nightreign itself a challenge.

The two new Nightlords are fun, engaging additions to Nightreign's boss canon; one is a group encounter that requires careful observation and management of multiple enemies, while the other is a classic, straightforward Soulslike battle with a fearsome, unpredictable foe.

They're tough, and they can test unprepared builds, but things really come to a head in the closing battles of each night prior to facing the Nightlords.

They contain some of Elden Ring Nightreign's most terrifyingly difficult fights, and if you're unprepared, you might find yourself scuppered. Expect to be thwarted at the end of day two more often than you're beaten by the Nightlords themselves.

That's fine in Elden Ring itself - or, indeed, any Soulslike with a liberal checkpoint system - but Nightreign's boss run is essentially two entire in-game day cycles of exploring Limveld, so it can feel frustrating to fall at the final hurdle, knowing you'll have to repeat everything that's come before just for a chance to try again.

This is another reason you're going to want Nightfarers whom you trust by your side. Limveld isn't playing around, and players who don't know The Forsaken Hollows' encounters can quickly be overwhelmed by its punishing difficulty.

There Isn't Quite Enough in The Forsaken Hollows

Of course, punishing difficulty and bosses that reward careful observation and planning are part and parcel of the Soulslike experience, so even though The Forsaken Hollows pushes things just a tad too far, it's still got some worthy additions to FromSoftware's boss canon.

The problem is that there just aren't quite enough of them. I counted eight new end-of-night bosses, all of whom return from either the original Elden Ring, its DLC, or a Dark Souls title (or associated DLC thereof).

That might sound like a lot at first, but things quickly get repetitive, and it wasn't long before I was sighing in disappointment at the same encounter being laid before me for the sixth or seventh time in a row.

I have no knowledge of the technical side of things, but I can't imagine it would have been too much work to throw a few more Elden Ring or Shadow of the Erdtree bosses into this DLC, and it would have gone a long way towards alleviating the repetition.

There are also no new weapons on offer, which feels like a bizarre and unfortunate oversight. Creating new builds and finding fun synergies was a big part of Nightreign, so the fact that there's no new red meat for the crazy theorycrafters is a shame.

Two new characters are available to play in The Forsaken Hollows, and for me, one was significantly more interesting than the other.

The Undertaker is...well, she's fine. Perhaps I haven't grasped the nuances of the play style yet, but she prioritizes aggression and damage, which is okay. She's a perfectly acceptable addition to Nightreign's roster, but I didn't find her particularly interesting.

However, the Scholar is a much more intriguing prospect. He's a support strategist, a role that none of Nightreign's other classes fulfil, and his abilities are powerful for a co-ordinated party that knows what it's doing.

Neither of these characters is quite enough to stave off The Forsaken Hollows feeling samey after a while, and they won't transform the game completely, but they're a fun enough diversion.

Elden Ring Nightreign: The Forsaken Hollows Review | Final Thoughts

Elden Ring Nightreign: The Forsaken Hollows is a worthwhile addition to the base game. 

Its new bosses are fun, its underground crystal area is atmospheric (if daunting), and hey, it's an excuse to head back into the excellent Nightreign itself. 

I just wish there was more of it, because repetition sets in far more quickly than I'd have liked. More weapons, a few more bosses, and perhaps one more Nightlord would have made this a must-play. 

As it is, if you loved Nightreign, check this out, but if you're hoping for a Mooncrash or Shadow of the Erdtree-style revelation, you're better off sleeping through this particular night.

Elden Ring Nightreign: The Forsaken Hollows was reviewed on PC with a copy provided by the publisher over the course of around 14 hours of gameplay. All screenshots were taken during the process of review.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph



https://techraptor.net/gaming/reviews/elden-ring-nightreign-forsaken-hollows-review-hard-reign

item.title: The Game Awards 2025: Everything Announced So Far (Updating Live)
item.content:encoded:
The biggest show in the world of gaming is back again tonight, December 11.

The Game Awards is back again to end this year with a celebration of the best games of 2025 and an exciting look into the future. While we may not know all the surprises in store for us this year, we do know we will be covering everything live and gathering it right here for you.

This article will be the place to catch all the biggest reveals, trailers, gameplay, shocking moments, and more, and we'll be updating it as it happens, so be sure to keep checking back!

Pragmata Gets Release Date, Demo, and Will Come to Nintendo Switch 2

Capcom's Pragmata is officially coming out on April 24, 2026, and The Game Awards also revealed it will have a gameplay demo out today and that it will also be coming to Nintendo Switch 2 alongside PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X/S.

Mario + Rabbids Creator Davide Soliani Announces New Platforming Game Bradley the Badger

Davide Soliani, the lead creator of the Mario + Rabbids games, stopped by The Game Awards to reveal his new platforming game, Bradley the Badger. This game is a classic platforming one with fresh twists and a meta-feeling story that is helping this video game mascot through its creator's unfinished work.

There were also some fun nods to Bloodborne, Cyberpunk 2077, The Last of Us, and more.

Stupid Never Dies Is Set in a World Where Monsters Are Part of Everyday Life And You Are a Lowly Zombie

Stupid Never Dies is set in a world where monsters are part of everyday life, and you take on the role of Davy, a lowly zombie who must brave a dungeon to bring back Julia, a frozen human he loved.

The Free Shepherd Kicks Off The Game Awards

An adorable game about a dog herding sheep called The Free Shepherd kicked off The Game Awards, but it's not coming out until 2027.

Decrepit Is a Terrifying First-Person Souls-Like Coming to PC in 2026

Get a new look at Decrepit, a terrifying first-person souls-like that is headed to PC in 2026. In this game, every death drags you back to the dungeons below, and you have to start fresh apart form the knowledge you gain from each escape attempt.

Audio Mech Gets a New Gameplay Trailer and a Demo Tomorrow

Your music powers Audio Mech, a new rhythm game from the creator of Audio Surf, and it lets you use such weapons as Bass Blade, Vocal Cannon, Treble Bombs, and more. Your music is your partner, and you can bring your own music into the game. Oh, and there is a demo out tomorrow.

Guild Wars 2 - Visions of Eternity Expansion Gets a New Trailer

Guild Wars is celebrating 20 years and the launch of its sixth expansion - Visions of Eternity - and this trailer is here to remind you of how much Guild Wars 2 has grown and what you can expect from this latest expansion.

Solasta 2 - Official Early Access Release Date Trailer

Solasta 2 is entering Early Access on March 12, 2026, and you can check out a look at the game right here. For those unfamiliar, Solasta 2 is a a turn-based RPG sequel based on tabletop RPG systems, and it features such talent as Amelia Tyler (Baldur's Gate III, Hades II) as Shadwyn, Ben Starr (Clair Obscur: Expedition 33, Final Fantasy XVI) as Rickard Colwall, Devora Wilde (Clair Obscur: Expedition 33, Baldur's Gate III) as Deorcas Colwall, and Ellen Thomas (Arcane) as Anabasia.

Developing...

In This Article
